reference.title: Snapshot and rollback
reference.shortdesc: There are times when taking a backup of an entire application is not practical, but you need a way to safeguard potential risk when changing your system. In these cases, it might be more beneficial to use to take a snapshot of the system, and then rollback if your changes cause a failure or other degradation of the application.

section.p: The main advantage of taking a snapshot over a backup is that you do not have to stop any services when taking a snapshot. You can take a snapshot whenever you need a savepoint for your Docker image, for example, before committing container changes or installing a ZenPack. If you want to back out your changes, you can use the rollback functionality to go back to the snapshot image.

When you take a snapshot, a tag is created for the Docker image of each service and a backup is taken of the distributed file system. You do not have to stop any services to create the snapshot, but if you do need to rollback, you must stop the particular services that are used by the snapshot image.

Since snapshots are meant as a savepoint and are not meant to be used as an historical backup, there is a default time to live (TTL) value of 12 hours for any snapshot. However, if you decide that you want to keep a snapshot beyond the TTL, you can tag the snapshot, which prevents it from being deleted after the TTL expires.
